group.label: • Release 1.0.7 new features
group.text:
Database entities editors redesign: To improve their usability and readability, database entities editors have been completely refactored to take advantage of the Eclipse Forms UI framework. We wanted to provide easy and fluid navigation throughout the editors. We think these new editors will make database developments with neXtep designer IDE a lot easier.
Don't hesitate to give us feedback about those new editors through our support forum!

group.text:
Improved Oracle support: Composite function-based indexes are now supported, and huge column's default values are now properly handled.

And of course a lot of bug fixes!

group.label: • Why this update?
group.text: Reference data is part of your database application : without them your application will probably not run at all. As such, static data should be completly integrated with your application lifecycle. So far, neXtep had very light support for reference data and that required to have a separate mechanism which could handle the data.

group.label: • How that works ?
group.text:
We extended the already existing concept of data sets which you can define on any neXtep-managed table. With 1.0.5 you can synchronize your data sets with any database : this allows you to compare the data you have in the repository with database contents and offers you to generate data re-alignment scripts or to import external data back into the repository in order to put them under version control. The approach is very similar to a structural synchronization : same perspective, same controls, same actions. Only the internal mechanisms is new.

The dataset editor has been completly redesigned and is now built on top of a SQL client. You can therefore query and update your data sets using regular SQL! Since we improved our SQL editors, you also have the option to edit data set contents directly inside the table.

group.label: • Known limitations
group.text:
We started to build a system which will be able to handle very large data sets without memory usage. With this first release, there is still some limitations when playing with large datasets (500k+ lines). For example, we did not workaround the MySQL JDBC driver limitation which loads all selected lines in memory (no streaming), we have some memory limitations on the SQL data generation which uses regular SQL scripts automatically displayed in the environment, which therefore need to be loaded in memory.

Not all datatypes are supported yet : tables containing CLOB and BLOB cannot be handled properly, user-defined datatypes are not supported (Oracle, DB2).

group.label: • Why this update?
group.text: Until now, the SQL client bundled with neXtep was very basic, unoptimized, and not very convenient to use. With the new support of reference data lifecycle, the ability of neXtep to easily query and manipulate the data becomes very strategic. We decided to rewrite a full-featured SQL client which we hope will become the core of data manipulation with neXtep.

group.label: • The SQL-client features
group.text:
Transaction support : The new SQL client now provides support for transactions for secure commit / rollback of your operations.

Externalized SQL results : The results of your SQL queries are placed in standalone views which you can place wherever you want. By default, one view is associated with one connection but you can pin any view to preserve its contents.

On the fly content edition : When you have queried a table, you can now toggle the edit mode which allows you to modify the data directly from the SQL result table, without writing any line of SQL. You can also add or remove any row and any erroneous data will be displayed. This option is only active when you select all primary key columns of a single table or when you do a select *.

Exports : You can export the results from any SQL query into a CSV file, customizable through preferences. You can also quickly copy / paste CSV-formatted text by selecting the rows you want and right-clic Copy.

Performance improvements : Our main concern was performance. We think it is pretty good since sort features are really fast, lines are displayed lazily and very quickly. Please send us your feedbacks through our forum.
